web_title: Mark Harper backs first-past-the-post: meet the man reshaping our politics
trail_text: Eurosceptic minister charged with referendum on electoral reform personally opposes a switch to alternative voting
headline: Mark Harper backs first-past-the-post: meet the man reshaping our politics
body:
David Cameron and Mark Harper, the constitutional affairs minister, can claim something in common. They were both taught at Brasenose College, Oxford, by Vernon Bogdanor, the professor of government, with whom they both disagreed but whose dream of a reformed British constitution, built around a more proportional electoral system, they may be about to realise.

Harper, the minister charged with guiding a referendum on a change to the voting system through parliament, says he personally opposes the proposed switch to the alternative vote (AV), arguing he fears the new voting system would make it more difficult to throw governments out.

Based in the Cabinet Office, there is no other Tory minister working in such proximity to Nick Clegg. Harper, a Eurosceptic and believer in first-past-the-post, admits cheerfully: "If you had said to me six months ago I would be working very closely together with the leader of the Liberal Democrats on constitutional and political reform I would be somewhat surprised. But I have also been surprised that there is a real sense of a team inside government."

It is his task to steer through the Commons a bill introducing five-year fixed term parliaments, a referendum on introducing the alternative vote, a 10% reduction in the size of the house and the biggest changes to constituency boundaries since the 1920s.

It promises to be a stormy passage. Observers calculate that the boundary changes – built round equalising the number of voters in a constituency – could be worth an extra 20 seats to the Tories. Labour calls it gerrymandering, and will oppose the bill at second reading. Harper insists this is a redressing of a current unfairness in the system.

Bogdanor, in an important piece in the Financial Times, this week set out the importance of this bill: "There is a temptation to believe that voters are being asked [in the referendum] to approve a mere technical change in the electoral system. Nothing could be more mistaken. The outcome will have massive political consequences. AV opens the door to a new political world in which coalitions become the norm, and single party majority government a distant memory. Defeat for AV could quickly end the coalition. But success would bind it together for a long time to come."

Since AV is a system in which voters can rank candidates by preference, it would allow the Tories and Lib Dems to put up candidates in every constituency, and ask supporters to give second preferences to their coalition partners – a natural way for the coalition to go through an election without a merger.

"The key thing the current system delivers is that it gives voters that essential sanction which says: 'This government is no good and I want it out.' That is why I will be campaigning for a no vote," says Harper.

"There is an additional argument about whether AV allows a coalition to move smoothly through an election period without everyone falling out with one another."

He denies it is contradictory to claim that coalitions are wrong in principle. "This government was partly formed in response to the circumstances of the time. This was about two parties coming together to deal with the severe circumstances we found ourselves in, but that does not mean we think this is the right model in perpetuity."

As soon as the bill is passed, £5m spending limits will be imposed on each of the two designated campaign organisations and £500,000 for any third party campaigns. May, he says, is a legitimate date as 83% of the country will be voting anyway and the Electoral Commission appears to have dropped objections to combining local elections and the referendum.

A range of forces will be voting no, says Harper, including many Conservative party members, most Tory MPs, some Labour MPs and unions. On the yes side will be the Lib Dems and possibly Labour, but he describes Labour as "all over the place on this issue".

He is eager to challenge the assumption that the second part of the bill, redrawing the boundaries, should be detached from the referendum. "Three things are going to happen. We are going to cut the size of the Commons by 7.5%. Secondly, we are equalising constituencies across the nations of the UK. Thirdly, the aim is to reduce the disparities in the size of seats so that no seats can be plus or minus 5% off a norm.

"For the first time it will be an absolute requirement that no constituency, apart from three exceptions, should be 5% larger or smaller in terms of constituents than the norm."

Harper accepts that making size pre-eminent ahead of geography and community will mean constituencies, for the first time, cross county and local council borders, and possibly split wards. "It is a trade-off. The thing we have said is that seats have to be more equal in size, so that votes are more equal in weight."

The review will be based on an electoral register prepared at the end of this year and completed by October 2013, giving political parties until May 2015 to select their candidates.

Labour says there is a lost army of voters – as many as 3.5 million unregistered, mainly poor voters. Harper questions that. "Best estimates suggest 92% of the electorate are registered to vote, and it is not true all these missing voters are in Labour seats."

He is looking at a bigger reform to clean up politics, including shifting from household to individual registration. "At present the head of the household registers all the other people in the household, but there is no means to check whether the people exist."

There have been allegations of voter fraud, but few prosecutions. Northern Ireland introduced the reform in 2006, since the country was perceived to have a bigger problem with fraud. The register fell sharply, and Harper said he was keen to ensure that people entitled to be on the register do not fall off.

Individual registration, like so much on Harper's desk, is no small reform. His predecessor, Michael Wills, said a year ago: "If we get this wrong and large numbers of people fall off the register, it would be a disaster. We can't have this botched." That goes for the rest of Harper's bulging briefcase, too.

web_title: Welfare reforms: women and large families are the losers
trail_text: Iain Duncan Smith says people will receive more, but an analysis shows that benefits will go to the main earner, mainly husbands, and will ignore the number of children in a family
headline: Welfare reforms: women and large families are the losers
body:
Iain Duncan Smith is not short of ambition. His white paper declares the universal credit system to be the most significant reform since the welfare state was created in 1947 by the towering Liberal thinker William Beveridge. What Duncan Smith offers appears to be the holy grail of social policy: simplifying the labyrinthine benefits system so that it guarantees welfare payments to a certain level of earnings, and then sees anyone who gets into work lose their entitlements at a fixed rate.

The minister is not wrong to say that a key route out of poverty is getting people back to work – many on benefits are doing an entirely rational thing by not taking jobs and thereby seeing their state handouts vanish precipitously. At present the poor face "penal tax rates", losing sometimes 90% of any earned income. Duncan Smith wants to get that down to 65%.

The question is whether universal credit is a win-win policy for everyone – or as Duncan Smith puts it, "there will be no losers". In fact his own white paper shows the rich losing out and the poor gaining to the tune of a few pounds a week. But given that the policy only begins in October 2013 for new claimants, it will come on the heels of housing benefit cuts which suck £12 a week next year from almost a million of Britain's poorest people. Singletons suffer as well – losing the right to earn £5 an hour without being taxed, a two-decade old policy meant to cover transport costs.

Women also find themselves apparently hit. The white paper makes it clear only one of the partners would receive the welfare payments. This means the child care component of the tax credit and the child element of the tax credit could end up in the pocket of the main earner, which many pressure groups say will be the man in a relationship. This would be a huge U-turn in policy – and the money is not trivial, with £100 a week at stake for bigger claims.

The new sanctions will also hurt and raise the possibility that the unemployed could lose their benefits for up to three years if they refuse work. Many who know the benefits system say this is unworkable. Those who suffer sanctions, they say, are often the least equipped to deal with the loss of income.

Duncan Smith says he will apply sanctions even to those with children. Anyone with a child over one will be expected to turn up regularly to a jobcentre – with the penalty that benefits will be cut if they don't. At present the system applies the full range of sanctions only to those with children over seven. The new proposals will reduce that to five. Juggling a complex life of childcare and penury is something that requires understanding, not a loss of cash from the state.

But there is good news. The amount of income that can be earned before benefits are withdrawn is set at a "cushion" of £110 a week for a couple with children. However bigger families will have to make do with the same amount – reinforcing the message that large poor families are a luxury that the state cannot subsidise.

There is now little doubt that benefits are being cut. Over the next few years £18bn is being lost from the Department for Work and Pensions budget – and only £2bn is set aside for the universal credit. This is the politics the government says the country can afford – rendering universal credit an expensive policy done cheaply.

web_title: Analysis: Preacher Duncan Smith aims for holy grail of welfare policy
trail_text: Analysis: The 'sin' of the benefits system may not be repaid in this parliament but in the next one, writes Randeep Ramesh
headline: Preacher Duncan Smith aims for holy grail of welfare policy
body:
Iain Duncan Smith's reforms to the welfare system carry more than a whiff of the preacher about them, with the cabinet minister telling Radio 4's Today programme that the current system, which trapped people in worklessness, was a "sin".

From a man with a Christian conscience, these are strong words indeed: sins have to be repaid first in this world and then again in the next. The road to perdition will never have been so crowded with Labour ministers atoning for past transgressions.

Little surprise, perhaps, that before the unemployed are saved from their indolence, they are treated to a dose of evangelical rhetoric around the much trailed universal credit. What Duncan Smith offers appears to be the holy grail of social policy: simplifying the labyrinthine benefits system so that it guarantees welfare payments to a certain level of earnings, and then sees anyone who gets into work lose their welfare entitlements at a fixed rate.

Duncan Smith is not wrong to say that a key route out of poverty is getting people back to work – many on benefits are doing an entirely rational thing by not taking jobs and thereby seeing their state handouts vanish precipitously. At present, the poor face "penal tax rates", losing sometimes 90% of any earned income. Duncan Smith wants to get that down to 65%.

But before the gain there appear to be years of pain. First, the atmosphere has changed: today's headlines about cracking down on those who refuse work appeal to a political constituency that sees those at the bottom of the pile as victims not of circumstance but of their own actions. In certain newspapers the unemployed have become "layabouts" and "malingerers".

Words may not hurt as much as the tough love Duncan Smith wants to administer. First, there are the new sanctions – raising the possibility that the unemployed could lose their benefits for up to three years if they refuse work. These will apply before the universal credit starts in October 2013. Many who know the benefits system say this is unworkable. Those who suffer sanctions, they say, are often the least equipped to deal with the loss of income.

Duncan Smith says he will apply sanctions even to those with children. Anyone with a child over one will be expected to turn up regularly to a jobcentre – with the penalty that benefits will be cut if you don't. At present, the system applies the full range of sanctions only to those with children over seven. The new proposals will reduce that to five. Juggling a complex life of childcare and penury is something that requires understanding, not a loss of cash from the state.

The second unseen effect is that, under the coalition's reforms, 1.4 million of the poorest people in Britain have been lifted into a marginal tax bracket that sees them lose more than 70% of any income they might earn. While Duncan Smith trumpets his reforms' intent to lower this in a few years' time, the working poor face higher rates of tax imposed via the chancellor's budget.

Lastly, there is now little doubt that benefits are being cut. Over the next few years, £18bn is being lost from the budget of the Department for Work and Pensions – and only £2bn is set aside for the universal credit. This is the politics the coalition government says the country can afford.

The universal credit is an expensive policy done cheap. You hand less to poor people and therefore have less to take away, making the universal credit affordable. This also makes poverty a work incentive, mimicking workfare in the United States, where benefit levels are so low that many people don't apply.

Duncan Smith also echoed arguments sold by Republicans that it was nonsense to claim that there are no jobs around, when immigrants rush to take up employment. The Tory welfare secretary said that 70% of all jobs created were taken by foreigners – a claim clearly rebutted by thinktanks.

The message over the weekend was that the long-term unemployed could be forced to carry out manual work to retain their benefits. This again is an American import: work requirements have long been used to force people off benefits. But the evidence from the US is mixed: during a recession, when jobs are scarce, the country has witnessed rising numbers on food stamps and in receipt of unemployment benefit.

Is the universal credit not really a weapon of mass destitution? Duncan Smith says not. More than 2 million will be materially better off, he says. But these are likely only to emerge in the next half of the decade, given that the universal credit starts taking on new claimants three years from now. Maybe a political sin cannot be redeemed in this parliament, but only in the next one.

trail_text: Andrew Sparrow with all today's politics news – including Iain Duncan Smith's white paper on welfare reform
headline: Politics live blog – Thursday 11 November 2010
body:
8.22am: It's a big day for the coalition. Iain Duncan Smith, the work and pensions secretary, is publishing his white paper on welfare reform, which is being described as the most radical overhaul of the system since Beveridge. Welfare ministers always say that about their plans to change the benefits system. But this time the claim may be rather more true than usual.

As Patrick Wintour and Randeep Ramesh report in the Guardian today, the proposals will include tough sanctions on those who refuse to work:

A tougher-than-expected squeeze on the unemployed is to be announced today as the jobless face the threat of losing all benefits for as long as three years if they refuse community work or the offer of a job, or fail to apply for a job if advised to do so.

In the most severe welfare sanctions ever imposed by a British government, unemployed people will lose benefits for three months if they fail to take up one of the options for the first time, six months if they refuse an offer twice, and three years if they refuse an offer three times.

Duncan Smith has already been giving interviews and he is due to formally launch his white paper at 8.30am, at an event in Camden, north London.

Elsewhere, David Cameron is at the G20 summit in Seoul and Alan Johnson, the shadow chancellor, is giving a speech about the economy at 11.15am.

As usual, I'll be covering all the breaking news, as well as looking at the papers and bringing you the best politics from the web.

8.29am: David Cameron has been talking about his reaction when he saw the pictures of demonstrators attacking the building where the Conservative HQ is based. "I was worried for the safety of people in the building because I know people who work in there, not just the Conservative Party but other offices as well," he told the BBC in an interview in Seoul. My colleague Patrick Wintour has the full story. Cameron said the government would not change its stance on tuition fees.

8.34am: Nick Clegg has told the BBC this morning that he "should have been more careful" before the election about signing the NUS pledge to vote against an increase in tuition fees. I think that's the closest he's come to admitting it was a mistake.

8.36am: Here are the main points from the interviews that Iain Duncan Smith has been giving this morning about the welfare reform white paper. I've taken the quotes from the Press Association and PoliticsHome (paywall).

• He said his main aim was to ensure that people always knew they would be better off in work.

We right now have a system that traps people, because it is complex, there are so many benefits withdrawn at different rates. People going back to work don't fully understand whether they are better off or worse, it is almost impossible to make that calculation. By simplifying and having one withdrawal rate we will actually make sure people will retain more of what they earn as they go back to work, thus making work pay more than being on benefits. That's the critical bit.

• He said it would take four years or more to introduce his reforms. "People will, I hope, recognise that we don't want to rush into this, we want to do this properly," he said.

• He described the plans as the biggest change to welfare "arguably since Bevan".

• He suggested that jobs would be available for the unemployed.

We're coming out of a recession. More jobs are being created.... In the last three months in the job centre over a million jobs went through the job centres and every week about 450,000 jobs are advertised in the job centres ... The key point is as the growth comes in the economy, as jobs are available all we're simply saying is 'you have a responsibility now that we're making work pay, now that we're going to help you, to actually take the work that's available'.

• He said that he expected only a very small number of claimants to lose benefits under the sanctions being proposed (see 8.22am). "We don't expect hardly anybody to be under those conditions, because people, when they recognise this will happen, I think will focus very seriously on taking work," he said.

• He said the archbishop of Canterbury was wrong to suggest that claimants would be punished. "Sanctions apply to those who won't cooperate when work is available, but no one's going to be punished," Duncan Smith said. "This is my point to the archbishop and others - this is not about punishing people for trying."

• He said he would not penalise disabled people who cannot work. "Those who are disabled and not expected to work will face no penalties at all," he said.

8.55am: The welfare reform white paper launch has just started. Nick Clegg, the deputy prime minister, is speaking. He has just described the proposals as "the most radical overhaul of our welfare system since its inception".

9.02am: Nick Clegg has finished his speech now. He ended with a lavish tribute to Iain Duncan Smith. "He deserves enormous credit for the policy we are putting forward today," Clegg said. Duncan Smith has "unrivalled expertise" in this area. Duncan Smith returned the compliment as he began his own speech. He said that Clegg's support had been very valuable. In other words, he seemed to be saying that Clegg was an ally in Duncan Smith's battles against the Treasury (who initially resisted Duncan Smith's plans).

9.09am: Duncan Smith says that he will outline the "specifics" of the white paper to parliament later. But now he is just going to talk about the broad principles, he says. (The Tories used to complain vigorously about Labour ministers making announcements outside parliament. Duncan Smith is leaving himself vulnerable to the same charge.)

9.12am: Duncan Smith has just produced some powerful figures about his plans.

• 2.5m households will have higher benefit entitlements under the new universal credit.

• 350,000 children will be lifted out of poverty under this plan.

• 500,000 adults will be lifted out of poverty.

• The number of workless households will fall by 300,000. That was "a conservative estimate", Duncan Smith said.

• 700,000 low earners will receive more under the universal credit.

9.21am: Duncan Smith is taking questions now, but I'm in Westminster, not Camden, and Sky and BBC News have dropped their live coverage. As soon as I get more, I'll post again. The white paper itself won't be available until Iain Duncan Smith delivers his statement in the Commons. That should be at about 12.20pm, after the business statement, although Nick Herbert, the police minister, is also due to make a statement about yesterday's student demonstration which may hold up the welfare statement, depending on which comes first.

9.32am: Douglas Alexander, the shadow work and pensions secretary, has offered qualified support for the plans in the welfare reform white paper.

If the Conservative government gets this change right, then we in the Labour party will support them, because there's common ground. If we can have a simpler benefits system that removes disincentives for people to get into work, we will support them. That was a big part of the work we were trying to take forward ourselves when we were in government.

But Alexander also pointed out that, if the reforms went wrong, "you could end up with a higher welfare bill not a lower welfare bill". That's because in-work benefits will become more generous than they are now, to ensure that people have an incentive to work. Duncan Smith made this clear with the figures he produced at his Camden launch. See 9.12am.

9.38am: I've already mentioned Nick Clegg apparently conceding that it was a mistake to sign the NUS pledge about not voting for an increase in tuition fees. (See 8.34am.) The Press Association has now filed the full quotes. Here they are:

I should have been more careful perhaps in signing that pledge. At the time I really thought we could do it. I just didn't know, of course, before we came into government, quite what the state of the finances were.

Clegg also seemed to accuse some of his Lib Dem colleagues of having their heads in the sand in relation to tuiton fees.

I guess the easiest thing for me would have been for me to say I've signed this pledge, I'm going to put my head in the sand, I'm not going to come up with a fair sustainable solution to universities and simply refuse to deal with it. I don't think that would have been the right thing. I wouldn't have been able to live, now that I'm in government, with the idea that because, yes, I had a policy before we went into government that I now realise we simply can't implement in practice, that I wasn't going to try and put something in place that will really help generations of particularly poor, bright kids who don't presently go to university.

That seemed to be aimed at Lib Dem MPs like Tim Farron and Sir Menzies Campbell who have said that, because they signed the pledge, there is no question of them changing their mind. Farron is quoted at the end of today's Guardian story. Campbell set out his views at length in a recent interview with me.

9.55am: David Cameron has had plenty to say in Seoul today. As my colleague Patrick Wintour has been reporting, he has praised the government's welfare reforms, insisted that yesterday's demonstration will not change policy on tuition fees, urged the world to tackle east-west trade imbalances and tried to revive England's bid for the 2018 World Cup.

But he's also found time to take a swipe at George Bush. He was asked about the claim in Bush's memoirs that waterboarding saved Britain from terrorist attack. In his reply, he suggested that that wasn't true.

Look, I think torture is wrong and I think we ought to be very clear about that. And I think we should also be clear that if actually you're getting information from torture, it's very likely to be unreliable information.

Cameron also suggested that Bush's decision to open Guantanamo Bay was counter-productive.

I think there is both a moral reason for being opposed to torture - and Britain doesn't sanction torture - but secondly I think there's also an effectiveness thing about what he said. Thirdly, I would say if you look at the effect of Guantanamo Bay and other things like that, long-term that has actually helped to radicalise people and make our country and our world less safe, so I don't agree.

10.29am: The full text of Iain Duncan Smith's speech about the white paper is on the Department for Work and Pensions' website now.

I haven't seen the full text of Nick Clegg's speech to the same event, but PoliticsHome (paywall) have put up extracts. The most interesting passage was the one where Clegg claimed that William Beveridge would have approved of today's white paper. Clegg said that Beveridge would have been unhappy with the benefits system as it operates now because he did not want it to encourage welfare dependency.

That is what today's announcements are about. Returning welfare in this country back to its original purpose. Nearly 70 years ago, its architect, the great Liberal William Beveridge imagined a system that gave people protection from cradle to grave but not one that would act as a crutch every day in between. Yes the state should offer security in hard times. But it should not, as Beveridge himself warned, stifle, incentive, opportunity, responsibility... Beveridge's dream has, however, been distorted.

11.11am: The Unite union has accused Iain Duncan Smith of trying to resurrect the Victorian distinction between the "deserving poor" and the "undeserving poor". This is from Gail Cartmail, Unite's assistant general secretary.

The atmosphere being created is of a division between the 'deserving' and 'undeserving' poor. We deny that such division exists. The income inequality in the UK is wider than most other OECD countries – those developed countries with whom the UK can most easily compare. This is because of low pay and gender discrimination, especially against part-time women workers. Government policy is pushing people into joblessness – the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD) latest forecast is 1.6m. The sums do not add up - divide unemployed into vacancies and there remains a lack of jobs already. Looking into the future the predicted joblessness is on a level not seen since the dole queues of the last Tory era of the 1980s.

11.29am: For the record, here are the latest YouGov GB polling figures.

Conservatives: 42% (up five points from general election)
Labour: 37% (up seven)
Lib Dems: 11% (down 13)

Government approval: -5

11.49am: You can read all today's Guardian politics stories here. And all the stories filed yesterday, including some in today's paper, are here.

As for the rest of the papers, here are four articles that I found interesting.

• John Rentoul in the Independent says that Phil Woolas should be allowed to stand again in Oldham East and Saddleworth, so that voters can have the final say about whether or not he remains as their MP.

It is not wrong in principle that an MP's election should be ruled void by the courts in these limited circumstances – it is, after all, the first case under this law and its similar precursor since 1911. The only question is whether it should then be for the people of Oldham East and Saddleworth to have the final say, by allowing Woolas to contest the re-run election. I think that the three-year disqualification is wrong, and that he should be allowed a final appeal to the court of his constituents.

• The Times (paywall) says that computer problems could hold up Iain Duncan Smith's plans to introduce a universal credit.

A new universal credit, merged from over 100 benefits, is due to be phased in from October 2013 with pilots running from March that year. However, the business plan for Revenue and Customs says the update to its PAYE system, essential for the new credit, will not be completed until April 2014.

The Times has now been told that ministers are already making contingency plans in case the system is not working in time. HMRC is planning to revamp its tax IT system so that income can be assessed weekly or monthly, rather than in arrears annually. This allows the Department for Work and Pensions to assess fluctuations in income — essential for the implementation of universal credit. A spokesman for the HMRC admitted yesterday that the new software was far from finalised and the Government still had to consult employers and payroll managers about the best design. The contract has not gone out to tender and the department has no estimates of the cost of the system.

• Benedict Brogan in the Daily Telegraph says that Tory MPs are showing signs of discontent.

The frequency of Tory rebellions is running at a post-war record. Members of the 1922 Committee executive, who act as the shop stewards for the parliamentary party, predict that the mid-term bruising endured by Barack Obama will come early for Mr Cameron, probably this time next year. "It's not the Tea Party he's got to worry about," goes the gag doing the rounds. "It's the tea room."

• Oliver Wright and Kevin Rawlinson in the Independent find out what has happened to various MPs who stood down or were defeated at the election after controversy about their expenses.

12.08pm: Iain Duncan Smith will be unveiling his welfare reform white paper in the Commons shortly. He has already delivered one speech on the subject this morning, but he made a point of saying that he would not be revealing the details until he spoke in the Commons. MPs get very shirty if they think government announcements are not being made on the floor of the House of Commons. We already know the broad outlines of what Duncan Smith is proposing. But we should learn a bit more, and we'll get a chance to read the white paper for the first time. We'll also get to find out how MPs react. Labour's Douglas Alexander has said that he supports the principle of what the government is trying to achieve, but some of his colleagues will probably be more critical.

12.17pm: Iain Duncan Smith is speaking now.

12.23pm: He says he has consulted as widely as possible about his plans, which are designed to ensure that people are better off in work.

He says there are 5 million people of working age on out-of-work benefit and almost 2 million children growing up in workless households.

12.25pm: Some have said that the priority should be jobs, he admits. But unemployment is a long-standing problem. Millions of people are detached from the labour market. These reforms are designed to bring them back in to the labour market.

By reducing the complexity of the system, he will reduce the opportunities for fraud and error, which currently cost the taxpayer £5bn a year.

Under the current system, people who get a job can end up losing more than £9 for every £10 they earn. Duncan Smith says that, under his reforms, the maximum marginal deduction rate (the amount someone loses in tax and benefits when they find work) will fall from 95.8% to 76.2%. Under the universal credit, the "taper" rate will be 65% (meaning that someone will get to keep at least 35p for every £1 they earn).

Duncan Smith repeats the figures he set out this morning about his proposals lifting 500,000 adults and 350,000 children out of poverty. (See 9.12am.)

12.33pm: Douglas Alexander is responding for Labour now. He says both parties want a simplified benefits system. If the government gets its reforms right, Labour will support them. He says pensions reform was the subject of cross-party agreement in the last parliament. He hopes the same will apply to welfare reform now.

Alexander says Duncan Smith originally proposed a taper rate of 55%. (He is referring to the green paper published by Duncan Smith in July.) Today's proposals are less generous, Alexander says. He suggests that the Treasury is to blame.

Alexander asks if Duncan Smith's figures about the impact of his plans on poverty (see 9.12am) take into account the impact of the government's welfare cuts.

Can Duncan Smith promise that he won't have to raid his budget for extra money if the costs of setting up the universal credit turn out to be higher than expected?

Alexander says Duncan Smith's claim to want to give people an incentive to find work are incompatible with his plans to cut housing benefit for the unemployed.

12.39pm: Duncan Smith is disappointed by Alexander's response. He says he expected him to be more positive about the plans.

The £2.1bn that has been set aside to set up this system during this spending review will be enough, he says. More money will be necessary in the next spending review period, because implementation will run into the next parliament. But money will be available for that too.

Duncan Smith says he is determined that the IT will be well managed. (He is making this point in response to today's Times story - see 11.49am.)

On the subject of the taper rate, Duncan Smith says everyone who goes back to work will be better off. If Labour wants a 55% rate, that's fine. But Labour will have to explain where the money would come from. Labour has not given an answer to that.

12.44pm: Roger Gale, a Conservative, suggests that the plan amounts to the introduction of "workfare". That's welcome, he says.

Anne Begg, the Labour chairman of the work and pensions committee, says creating a single benefit is the "holy grail" of welfare reform. She says she will support the plans if they work.

Peter Lilley, a Conservative former social security secretary, asks how he will deal with the problem that people might be reluctant to get a job because they fear losing housing benefit.

Duncan Smith says claimants will only have to make one application. It will be a "seamless process". This should ensure that people do not worry about losing benefit in the way Lilley suggested.

12.44pm: Duncan Smith says his reforms will particularly benefit women, because so many of them are in part-time work.

12.46pm: Jenny Willott, a Lib Dem MP, asks who will run the work programme.

Duncan Smith says the work programme will start next summer. There will be contracts involving the private sector and the voluntary sector. They will be paid by results.

Labour's Malcolm Wicks, a former welfare minister, welcomes what Duncan Smith is trying to achieve but asks if there will be enough jobs in the private sector.

Duncan Smith says more than 1m jobs have been available in job centres over the last three months.

12.47pm: Disability living allowance won't be included in the universal credit, Duncan Smith says, because it's not an out-of-work benefit.

12.47pm: Labour's Glenda Jackson asks for a guarantee that these changes will not be used by employers to drive down wage levels.

Duncan Smith says he hopes that Labour will not just "hope for the worst". Jackson should be glad about the prospect of the poorest 30% becoming richer, he says.

12.54pm: The SNP's Eilidh Whiteford says that she applauds what Duncan Smith is trying to do, but that she is still struggling to see where all the jobs will come from.

Duncan Smith says the universal credit will be implemented over a long period. The economy is growing, he says.

12.54pm: Philip Hollobone, a Conservative, asks how travel costs are taken into account in the universal credit. He says the cost of travelling can often make the difference between a job being worthwhile or not. Duncan Smith accepts this. He says more money will be available to pay people's travel costs because they will get to keep more of the money they earn.

12.58pm: Andrew George, a Liberal Democrat, asks if the plan to make the unemployed work will be a "stick" or a "carrot".

Duncan Smith says reports of this have been exaggerated. It will be an option available to advisers in job centres. For some people, it will help them get ready for work, because they will learn the discipline of doing a job. In other cases, where advisers suspect that someone is doing a job that they are not declaring, it will be used as a sanction. If they have to go on a work programme, they will not be able to claim benefit while doing a black market job at the same time.

1.02pm: Labour's Chuka Umunna asks about the Times story about computer problems holding up the implementation of universal credit. (See 11.49am.) Duncan Smith says the Department for Work and Pensions will not need to use the full capacity of HM Revenue and Customs' new system. It will only need to use a part of it, he says. He implies that the delay mentioned in the Times is not a problem.

1.04pm: Labour's Helen Goodman says that the unemployed should not have to take the first job available. There is no point having physics graduates working at a supermaket checkout, she says.

Duncan Smith says he is "disappointed" by her comment. The important thing is to get people into work, he says. At this point someone heckles him, suggesting that he does not have any experience of this. Duncan Smith angrily replies that he has been unemployed. At the time, he would have given anything to get a job, he says.

1.08pm: Duncan Smith insists that no one will lose out from his reforms.

1.08pm: Peter Bone, a Conservative, says the government needs to change the culture of worklessness. Duncan Smith says the work programme will achieve this.

1.08pm: Duncan Smith says that, listening to Labour, he cannot tell whether they are converted, or whether they "hate the idea that someone is doing something that they should have done 10 years ago".

1.10pm: Bob Russell, a Liberal Democrat, says children were mentioned only twice in Duncan Smith's statement. He asks if the sanctions will affect families with children.

Duncan Smith says his plans should lift 350,000 children out of poverty.

1.13pm: Labour's Cathy Jameison asks Duncan Smith if he supports the living wage.

Duncan Smith says his plan is the best way to ensure that households end up with a living wage.

1.14pm: Labour's David Winnick says that in the "real world" 18 people are chasing every vacancy. Some of Duncan Smith's comments are reminiscent of Norman Tebbit's claim that the unemployed should "get on their bikes".

Duncan Smith says Winnick should welcome the statement.

1.16pm: Labour's Fiona Mactaggart says that in Slough the average bus fare is £3.50. A woman who gets a part-time job could find much of her extra money eaten up by her bus fare. Will Duncan Smith help people pay their travel costs?

Duncan Smith says that if people have more money, they will have more money to pay their travel costs.

1.33pm: What sort of response did Beveridge get when he unveiled his great plan for the welfare state? Does anyone know? Iain Duncan Smith was clearly expecting a much better reception than he got, and by the end of his statement he was sounding distinctly tetchy.

Anne Begg (who chairs the select committee that deals with this issue) was spot on when she described a single, unified benefit of the kind proposed by Duncan Smith as the "holy grail" of welfare reform. (See 12.44pm.) Duncan Smith seemed to think he deserved a hero's welcome.

Most Labour MPs said they supported what he was trying to do in principle, but it did not take them long to start hurling objections, raising from the churlish to the utterly reasonable (of which the most important was - will there be enough jobs?) This is certainly policy making at its boldest. Whether it turns out to be a success or not is, at this stage, frankly anyone's guess. I have not seen the white paper yet, but it should be on the department's website soon.

2.12pm: Here, a little later than usual, is a lunchtime summary.

• Iain Duncan Smith said that 500,000 adults and 350,000 children would be lifted out of poverty under this plans to reform the welfare statement. The work and pensions secretary released the figures as he published a long-awaited white paper on welfare reform. Nick Clegg, the deputy prime minister, described the proposals as "the most radical overhaul of our welfare system since its inception". Labour's Douglas Alexander said that the opposition would support the proposals in principle, but - to Duncan Smith's apparent disappointment - most Labour MPs who spoke in the Commons were sceptical about whether the government's plans would actually achieve what they were supposed to.

• Alan Johnson, the shadow chancellor, has said that the economy was too reliant on the City when Labour was in power. In a speech, he said Britain's tax base was "less resilient" than it should have been before the banking crisis struck because the Exchequer was so reliant on tax revenue from the financial services industry, and also tax revenue related to rising house prices. Johnson said Labour would try to amend the legislation setting up the Office for Budget Responsibility so that the OBR has to make a regular assessment of the resilience of the tax base. He used used the speech to challenge at length claims that Labour let spending get out of control in the last parliament.

• Nick Clegg has said that he should have been "more careful" about signing the NUS pledge promising to vote against an increase in tuition fees. In an interview on ITV's Daybreak, he said: "I should have been more careful perhaps in signing that pledge. At the time I really thought we could do it." He also suggested that his Lib Dem colleagues who are refusing to back the government's plans have their heads in the sand. In his speech, Alan Johnson said the Lib Dem U-turn over tuition fees was "probably the most cynical political betrayal I have ever witnessed".

• Nick Herbert, a Home Office minister, has criticised the way the police handled yesterday's demonstration against tuition fees. In a statement to MPs, Herbert said: "The police have to strike a balance between dealing promptly and robustly with violence and unlawful activity on the one hand, and allowing the right to protest on the other. Clearly, in this case, the balance was wrong. But these are difficult decisions and they are not taken lightly." Sir Paul Stephenson, the Metropolitan police commissioner, said today that some officers "came perilously close to being seriously injured" during the protests.

• The Conservative party has suspended a councillor who posted a comment on Twitter suggesting that the columnist Yasmin Alibhai-Brown should be stoned to death. "Language of this sort is not acceptable and as a result Gareth Compton's membership of the Conservative party has been indefinitely suspended pending further review," a party spokesperson said.

• David Cameron has cast doubt on George Bush's claim that waterboarding prevented a terrorist attack against Britain. In an interview in Seoul, the prime minister said: "I think torture is wrong and I think we ought to be very clear about that. And I think we should also be clear that if actually you're getting information from torture, it's very likely to be unreliable information."

• Cameron also said world leaders must resolve trade imbalances. Speaking at the start of the G20 summit, he said: "The biggest issue of all is the cause of the last crisis – a wall of money in the east, a wall of debt in the west. We've got to deal with that imbalance and I think it's a real test for this summit and one that Britain will play a very positive part in trying to make sure we really look at these imbalances and deal with them."

3.07pm: The Tory councillor who posted a comment on Twitter about Yasmin Alibhai-Brown being stoned to death (see 2.12pm) has now been arrested. My colleagues Peter Walker and David Batty have the full story here:

Police in Birmingham today arrested a Conservative city councillor who sent a Twitter message saying that the newspaper columnist Yasmin Alibhai-Brown should be stoned to death.

Alibhai-Brown said last night she would report Gareth Compton, a councillor for the Erdington district, to police following the tweet.

Compton was arrested last night and bailed after questioning. A spokeswoman for West Midlands police said: "We can confirm a 38-year-old man from Harborne has been arrested for an offence under section 127 (1a) of the Communications Act of 2003 on suspicion of sending an offensive or indecent message. He has been bailed pending further inquiries."

3.08pm: What sort of response did Beveridge get when he unveiled his welfare plans, I asked earlier. My colleague Martin Kettle points out that when Beveridge published his report, people queued all night to get hold of a copy and the first print run sold out immediately. Iain Duncan Smith's document – which runs to 68 pages and is called Universal Credit: Welfare that Works – is unlikely to do so well. If you do want to buy a copy, it'll cost you £19.75, I see. But you can download it for free here.

But another reader emailed me to say that there may be some similarities between Beveridge and Duncan Smith.

The Beveridge report was received with great approval among the public according to the Ministry of Information but the parliamentary reaction was perhaps not dissimilar. It was decided that, as it was published in 1942, it was welcomed in principle, but that, given the war and the unclear future, the plan should not be put into practice until the financial situation was clearer after the war ... But the Tories and the Liberals quickly adopted the report's proposals, while Labour were sceptical about Beveridge's idea of a National Health Service (envisaged as run through local health centres and regional hospital administrations) because they preferred a state-run body instead ... Nevertheless, Labour started implementing the report after the war and Beveridge was elevated to the Lords as a Liberal peer.

3.21pm: Phil Woolas's judicial review against the election court decision removing him from parliament will start on Tuesday next week, the BBC and Sky are reporting.

3.30pm: Plenty of reaction to the welfare white paper is now coming in. Here's a selection of comment from welfare charities. Generally, they seem to be very sceptical.

From Kate Wareing, Oxfam's director of UK Poverty:

Changes to the benefits system proposed today will expose people to the risk of destitution. Removing benefits and leaving people with no income will result in extreme hardship for them and their families. This sanction, and the proposals to force people to do unpaid work are based on stigma. Most people receiving benefits do want to work, and punishing them as if they are criminals repaying a debt to society is not a fair way to treat someone entitled to support.

From Richard Hawkes, chief executive of disability charity Scope:

Despite a progressive vision, this white paper does not address the state of the employment market today, nor take into consideration the reality of people's lives. And worryingly, it plans to introduce a "regime of sanctions for those that don't play by the rules". What about those disabled people who do play by the government's rules? Who try repeatedly to get work but are not successful?

From Fiona Weir, chief executive of the single parent charity Gingerbread:

Gingerbread welcomes government moves to make work pay and to simplify the benefits system but warns that without more jobs that fit with school hours, and help with childcare costs, thousands of single parents will stay trapped on benefits. Gingerbread is also very concerned that single parents could face the threat of sanctions. Most single parents want to work but find the odds heavily stacked against them and the effect of financial sanctions would plunge children into unacceptable levels of poverty.

From Helen Dent, chief executive of Family Action:

The existing sanctions regime creates sufficient incentives to actively seek work, and to take job opportunities when they are offered. Further toughening of sanctions for jobseekers would be unnecessarily punitive, and would not tackle the key issues of job availability, and the provision of holistic support which many of our service users need to make employment sustainable.

3.33pm: Here's the statement that the Labour press office has issued from Douglas Alexander, the shadow work and pensions secretary. In interviews this morning Alexander sounded broadly supportive (see 9.32am). He has not contradicted himself, but his tone is now definitely more negative.


We support the underlying principle of simplifying the benefits system and providing real incentives to work.

My concern is that George Osborne's recent actions reveal he doesn't support these principles - he has already both complicated the system and undermined incentives to work through changes such as the reduction in working tax credit.

Some of the key aspects of Iain Duncan Smith's original plan already seem to have been cut and that could mean some people facing bigger barriers to getting back to work.

And our overriding concern is that there is a fatal flaw at the heart of these proposals - without work they won't work.

3.43pm: Here's an afternoon reading list.

• Paul Goodman at ConservativeHome on David Cameron.

Cameron is a born leader, who reminds me, as he may other readers of a certain age, of "Grabber" in the Molesworth books, who was "Head of Skool, Captain of Everything, and winner of the Mrs Joyful Prize for Rafia Work". He listens, thinks, makes decisions - generally in that order - cracks jokes, writes nice notes to staff, and above all doesn't panic. Like Macmillan again, who was fond of quoting the lines from Gilbert and Sullivan, he believes that "quiet, calm deliberation disentangles every knot". Tony Blair would have milked the Commons Bloody Sunday statement, announced a new gun crackdown after the Cumbria shootings, and been photographed in full-dress uniform chairing COBRA after the Yemen bomb plot. That Cameron did none of these things, but simply got on with the business of government in each case, made me want to stand on a chair and cheer. This undemonstrativeness shouldn't be mistaken for weakness. John Major once said: "When your back's to the wall, it's time to turn round and fight". Cameron wouldn't say exactly the same (as a former colleague pointed out, why pick on the wall?), but he doesn't crack when pushed into a corner, as he proved with the noteless speech at the 2007 Conference which played a part in staving off a snap election.


• Alex Barker at the FT's Westminster blog says there are losers from Iain Duncan Smith's welfare reforms. They are people in the top four deciles, meaning they are relatively well-off.

• Tom Watson on his blog on what works of art ministers are hanging on their office walls.


Chancellor George Osborne shows that he likes it big and bold – he has opted for a 6 foot wide oil by the famous nonsense poet Edward Lear. Lear's painting, 'View of Beirut', presents a romantic image many years before the area was torn apart in a civil war. In addition, on Osborne's wall hangs a 7ft long engraved map by Grayson Perry. It depicts a divided country, at war with itself, with the instructional title of 'Print for a Politician'. It begs the question whether he bought it to learn cartography, or did the message of diversity just appeal. £68,727 worth of artwork lines the Chancellor's walls in total – based on the values given for when the artwork was acquired.

3.59pm: Here's an afternoon summary.

• Welfare groups have responded with scepticism to Iain Duncan Smith's plans for welfare reform. Despite claims that the proposals will lift nearly 1m adults and children out of poverty, charities have complained that the sanctions are too punitive and that Duncan Smith seems to be placing too much reliance on the creation of jobs that may not materialise. Brendan Barber, the TUC general secretary, has criticised the plans. "Some people will undoubtedly make small gains, but it is poor and vulnerable people, as well as working families on middle incomes, who will pay for most of those gains through the government's £18 billion programme of welfare cuts," he said. Labour also seems to be adopting a more critical tone. (See 3.30pm and 3.33pm.)

• The Tory councillor who sent a Twitter message saying that the newspaper columnist Yasmin Alibhai-Brown should be stoned to death has been arrested. (See 3.07pm.)

• Simon Hughes, the Lib Dem deputy leader, has attacked Labour MPs for their decision to support Phil Woolas. "Labour's leaders had spoken but since then many Labour MPs have come out in support of Phil Woolas both on and off the record," Hughes said in a statement. "The judgement of the court was clear: Phil Woolas made statements which were not about Liberal Democrat politics but personal attacks on our candidate's character and conduct which he had no reasonable grounds for believing were true and did not believe were true. Residents in Oldham East and Saddleworth and across the country will not understand why the Labour Party won't say clearly, with one voice, that there is no place in British politics for this kind of behaviour." Hughes made his statement as it emerged that Woolas's judicial review of the election court decision will begin next Tuesday.

• It has emerged that the government would be able to transfer some minor powers to the EU without a referendum under the government's EU bill. The bill, which has been published today, is designed to ensure that there has to be a referendum if the government wants to transfer any powers to Brussels. But, as the BBC reports, the legislation shows this so-called "referendum lock" will not apply if proposed treaty changes are not "significant".

• William Hague, the foreign secretary, has named the members of his new advisory group on human rights. As he says in a statement, they will meet twice a year and they will not be paid.

That's it for today. Thanks for the comments.

headline: Welfare reform: Find a job or lose benefits, mothers to be told
body:
All stay at home mothers claiming the government's new universal credit will be required to make themselves available for work or lose state support, putting them on a par with single parents for the first time. The requirement would apply to mothers with children aged over seven.

The proposals came in the government's welfare bill published on Thursday and were hailed by David Cameron as "tough, radical ... but fair".

His remarks came as ministers published a raft of figures alongside the bill, for the first time showing the full impact of the introduction of universal credit and other welfare cutbacks announced by ministers. The figures show 1.7m households will lose out from the universal credit reforms.

Nearly 75% of these will suffer reductions of less than £25 per week, but 100,000 households will lose more than £75 a week. The biggest losers, the Department of Work and Pensions (DWP) said, are likely to be single people without children, those working more than 30 hours, those not in receipt of housing benefit, and households with savings of more than £16,000.

Ministers have insisted there will be no losers, but this only holds true at the point of transition onto the new scheme due to a special fund set up to temporarily compensate those whose benefits are due to be cut. A total of 100,000 claimants – those in the poorest 40% – are expected to gain by at least £4,000 a year. A further 1m households will see an increase in income of at least £25 a week. Improved entitlements and take-up should mean 300,000 children are taken out of poverty.

The new universal credit, largely constructed by the work and pensions secretary Iain Duncan Smith while in opposition, is a single benefit for working-age adults. It unifies the current myriad system of means-tested out-of-work benefits, tax credits and support for housing. All three parties have backed the principle of the reforms, but the shadow work and pensions secretary Liam Byrne expressed misgivings about the lack of funding and the difficulty of introducing the change at a time of high unemployment.

Cameron claimed that perverse incentives and complexities within the existing system had "insidiously drained hope away from swathes of our society", and actively encouraged people to behave in ways which were irresponsible. The universal credit will be introduced at a net annual cost of £2.6bn from October 2013 with all claimants on the scheme by 2017.

The DWP assessment, published alongside the bill, also suggests the government intends to save £2bn from cutting back on fraud and administrative error.

In cases of suspected fraud, ministers will introduce a new minimum penalty of £350, or 50% of the amount overpaid, whichever is greater, up to a maximum of £2,000.

To encourage personal responsibility a new civil penalty of £50 will be payable for anyone negligent in maintaining their benefit claim. Cautions will no longer be part of the DWP sanctions policy.

But the system will see increased take-up costing an extra £2bn annually and another £2.7bn because of higher extra entitlements. These figures exclude other savings to the welfare budget. The details also suggest ministers have still to resolve some key issues including how credit is to be paid and whether to include child tax credit and council tax benefit. It has been decided to exclude carers allowance.

Plans to cut housing benefit by 10% for those unemployed for more than a year have been dropped. The DWP also estimates that a cap on housing benefit for workless households will see 50,000 households have their benefits reduced, losing on average around £93 per week and leading to evictions.

Before the introduction of universal credit, the sanctions regime will be tightened.

In a disturbing assessment, the Association of Learning Providers (ALP), the body that represents work providers, also warned that the plans to pay work providers by results "is fraught with risks which may impact significantly on the number of unemployed people who can benefit from it".

The ALP warns the funding for the scheme is too tight, alongside very high performance expectation that equate to the highest levels ever achieved under the Labour government's New Deal, a work programme delivered at a time of much lower unemployment.

Graham Hoyle, the ALP chief executive, warned the whole programme's operation is in danger.

The Social Market Foundation, a thinktank, criticsed the attack on savers estimating that there are around 400,000 families with children who have savings above £16,000 currently receive tax credits.

New claimants will be denied payments if their savings exceed the £16,000 limit.

Ian Mulheirn, Director of the SMF said the rules will "send all the wrong signals" to families on benefits about the need to save and be prudent.

Cameron said the decision to dump the proposal for a 10% housing benefit cut after 12 months showed that the government was listening.

He said: "This was a proposal made before the statement and development of the universal credit."

However other cuts in housing benefit support remain. Cameron described the reforms as "tough, radical... but fair".

Cameron said: "I know this country and therefore refuse to believe that there are 5 million people who are inherently lazy and have no interest in bettering themselves and their families. "Making low-income working families thousands of pounds worse off through welfare cuts over the next two years to claim that they will be slightly better off in 2013 is an absurd argument that will ring hollow as families suffer the toughest income squeeze for nearly a century."
